____________________________________________________________

Understanding context and culture in the parenting approaches of immigrant South Asian mothers

Author: Maiter, Sara; George, Usha

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215401161?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study of the parenting approaches of immigrant South Asian Canadian mothers found that character formation and identity formation were the mothers' key goals of parenting. Internalized cultural values, beliefs, and norms and external factors related to their social context and environment, such as collectivism, dual socialization, and environmental stress, guided the mothers' approaches to parenting. Social service providers need to be aware that racial-minority mothers think through their approaches to parenting to respond to social contexts that have negative consequences for their children and should include this understanding in their provision of services [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+context+and+culture+in+the+parenting+approaches+of+immigrant+South+Asian+mothers&amp;rft.au=Maiter%2C+Sara%3BGeorge%2C+Usha&amp;rft.aulast=Maiter&amp;rft.aufirst=Sara&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=411&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Transitional supportive housing programs: Battered women's perspectives and recommendations

Author: Melbin, Anna; Sullivan, Cris M; Cain, Debra

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388751?accountid=14667

Abstract: Finding safe, affordable housing is one of the greatest obstacles that women who leave abusive partners face. In response, advocates for battered women have begun to offer transitional supportive housing (TSH) programs. This article reports on interviews with 55 key stakeholders of these programs (direct service staff, current participants, former participants, and shelter residents) to examine the degree to which TSH programs fulfill the needs of the women who use them. Consistent with other research on empowerment-based services, the study found that the women were most satisfied when services were provided in a respectful and individualized manner. The women's recommendations included the implementation of safety protocols and the need for a variety of support services that should be offered but not mandated. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Transitional+supportive+housing+programs%3A+Battered+women%27s+perspectives+and+recommendations&amp;rft.au=Melbin%2C+Anna%3BSullivan%2C+Cris+M%3BCain%2C+Debra&amp;rft.aulast=Melbin&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=445&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Focus-group methodology in research with incarcerated women: Race, power, and collective experience

Author: Pollack, Shoshana

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215380247?accountid=14667

Abstract: Feminist researchers have found focus groups to be valuable for understanding collective experiences of marginalization, developing a structural analysis of individual experiences, and challenging taken-for-granted assumptions about race, gender, sexuality, and class. These benefits are in contrast to individual interviews, which may lend themselves to privatized and individualistic accounts of gendered experiences and which risk reproducing colonizing relationships and discourses. This study used both individual interviews (life-history methodology) and focus-group interviews to examine the effects of marginalization and oppression on Black Canadian women's lawbreaking. Combining these two methodologies may be particularly fruitful in cross-cultural and/or cross-racial research and in contexts such as correctional institutions, where issues of power and disclosure are amplified. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Focus-group+methodology+in+research+with+incarcerated+women%3A+Race%2C+power%2C+and+collective+experience&amp;rft.au=Pollack%2C+Shoshana&amp;rft.aulast=Pollack&amp;rft.aufirst=Shoshana&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=461&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Focus-group+methodology+in+research+with+incarcerated+women%3A+Race%2C+power%2C+and+collective+experience&amp;rft.au=Pollack%2C+Shoshana&amp;rft.aulast=Pollack&amp;rft.aufirst=Shoshana&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=461&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Preventing developmental disabilities and promoting maternal and child health: Women organizing for change

Author: Wilson, Ann M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395640?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mental retardation and related developmental disabilities affect 1.5% of the population in the United States. Efforts to address preventable developmental disabilities - such as those caused by lead poisoning, fetal alcohol syndrome, and traumatic brain injuries - have been the focus of activities in one state for almost 20 years. These efforts were created, and have been organized and sustained, by women. The prevention coalition was established to foster cooperation, identify and develop resources, and advocate for programs, services, and legislation. The coalition further promotes the development of leaders in the human services and public health fields and embraces feminist principles of collaboration, mutual support, nurturance,and self-empowerment in its organizing efforts. Implications for community organizing and development, public awareness and community education around primary prevention issues, legislative advocacy, mentoring and coaching of emerging leaders, community partnerships, and social change are discussed. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Preventing+developmental+disabilities+and+promoting+maternal+and+child+health%3A+Women+organizing+for+change&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+Ann+M&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=473&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Preventing+developmental+disabilities+and+promoting+maternal+and+child+health%3A+Women+organizing+for+change&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+Ann+M&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=473&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

My doctoral journey: A Chinese woman's struggles

Author: Chan, Zenobia C Y

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390433?accountid=14667

Abstract: Now that the author has finished her doctoral thesis in social welfare but has not yet taken her oral examination, she wants to share the experience of her struggles in the past 3 years of nonstop studying. The completion of her studies motivated her to reveal her experiences as a Chinese woman who had been a housewife for 6 years before she entered the doctoral program. This was really a critical turning point for her in changing her social identity from a woman who was locked in the family domain to a female elite who could be accepted in the academic domain. However, then as now, she is filled with a strong passion for expressing women's voices, has a commitment to social justice, and is inspired to add to the knowledge base in her field. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=My+doctoral+journey%3A+A+Chinese+woman%27s+struggles&amp;rft.au=Chan%2C+Zenobia+C+Y&amp;rft.aulast=Chan&amp;rft.aufirst=Zenobia+C&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=479&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=My+doctoral+journey%3A+A+Chinese+woman%27s+struggles&amp;rft.au=Chan%2C+Zenobia+C+Y&amp;rft.aulast=Chan&amp;rft.aufirst=Zenobia+C&amp;rft.date=2003-12-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=479&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Author: Dinerman, Miriam

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215380399?accountid=14667

____________________________________________________________

Rethinking empowerment theory using a feminist lens: The importance of process

Author: Carr, E Summerson

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215398661?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article highlights the importance of social, historical, and political context when theorizing empowerment and "maps " empowerment as a cyclical, rather than a linear, process. Synthesizing important perspectives in feminist thought and empowerment theory, it proposes understandings of positionality, conscientization, and social transformation that are meant to inform empowerment-oriented, feminist social work practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Rethinking+empowerment+theory+using+a+feminist+lens%3A+The+importance+of+process&amp;rft.au=Carr%2C+E+Summerson&amp;rft.aulast=Carr&amp;rft.aufirst=E&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=8&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Rethinking+empowerment+theory+using+a+feminist+lens%3A+The+importance+of+process&amp;rft.au=Carr%2C+E+Summerson&amp;rft.aulast=Carr&amp;rft.aufirst=E&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=8&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Capturing the complexity of women's experiences: A mixed-method approach to studying incontinence in older women

Author: Shapiro, Margaret; Setterlund, Deborah; Cragg, Carole

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215401569?accountid=14667

Abstract: Capturing the voices of women when the issue is of a sensitive nature has been a major concern of feminist researchers. It has often been argued that interpretive methods are the most appropriate way to collect such information, but there are other appropriate ways to approach the design of research. This article explores the use of a mixed-method approach to collect data on incontinence in older women and argues for the use of a variety of creative approaches to collect and analyze data.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Capturing+the+complexity+of+women%27s+experiences%3A+A+mixed-method+approach+to+studying+incontinence+in+older+women&amp;rft.au=Shapiro%2C+Margaret%3BSetterlund%2C+Deborah%3BCragg%2C+Carole&amp;rft.aulast=Shapiro&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Capturing+the+complexity+of+women%27s+experiences%3A+A+mixed-method+approach+to+studying+incontinence+in+older+women&amp;rft.au=Shapiro%2C+Margaret%3BSetterlund%2C+Deborah%3BCragg%2C+Carole&amp;rft.aulast=Shapiro&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The journey from welfare to work: Learning from women living in poverty

Author: McPhee, Debra M; Bronstein, Laura R

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388525?accountid=14667

Abstract: This multiphase study was designed to gain a qualitative understanding of the experiences of single-mother welfare recipients and the effect of welfare reforms on recipients' perceived ability to care for themselves and their families. The findings were drawn from the first phase of the study in which individual interviews were conducted with 39 current or former recipients, all of whom were women o color living in socioeconomically disadvantaged urban neighborhoods. Eight themes are analyzed, and the implications for social welfare policy and practice are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+journey+from+welfare+to+work%3A+Learning+from+women+living+in+poverty&amp;rft.au=McPhee%2C+Debra+M%3BBronstein%2C+Laura+R&amp;rft.aulast=McPhee&amp;rft.aufirst=Debra&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=34&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Incorporating spirituality in feminist social work perspectives

Author: Coholic, Diana

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215396094?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes a qualitative study of 20feminist social workers' conceptualizations of spirituality and spiritually influenced practices. A grounded-theory analysis of the interviews uncovered major convergences among the participants' values and practices, which encouraged the development of a set of practice principles, One such practice principle, which encompasses the commonalities between feminist social work and spiritual values and practices and the desire for holistic approaches, is discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Incorporating+spirituality+in+feminist+social+work+perspectives&amp;rft.au=Coholic%2C+Diana&amp;rft.aulast=Coholic&amp;rft.aufirst=Diana&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Heeding new voices: Gender-related herstories of Asian and Caribbean-born elderly women

Author: Patterson, Fiona M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388603?accountid=14667

Abstract: Older women who came to this country as adults have had little or no voice in public discourse, including feminist discussions of women's experiences, needs, and roles. This qualitative exploratory study of how life events affected the aging of 25 women born in Puerto Rico, the West Indies, China, India, and Korea investigated the women's early lives and current relationships with their husbands and other family members. Ways for the information gleaned to enhance social work with this population are also explored.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Heeding+new+voices%3A+Gender-related+herstories+of+Asian+and+Caribbean-born+elderly+women&amp;rft.au=Patterson%2C+Fiona+M&amp;rft.aulast=Patterson&amp;rft.aufirst=Fiona&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=68&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Heeding+new+voices%3A+Gender-related+herstories+of+Asian+and+Caribbean-born+elderly+women&amp;rft.au=Patterson%2C+Fiona+M&amp;rft.aulast=Patterson&amp;rft.aufirst=Fiona&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=68&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Social motherhood revisited

Author: Julie Cooper Altman

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215386653?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the way social workers have used this socially defined role to legitimate and solidify the profession, examine its consequences for social work, and propose one idea, perhaps controversial, for a creative synthesis of this role dilemma.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Social+motherhood+revisited&amp;rft.au=Julie+Cooper+Altman&amp;rft.aulast=Julie+Cooper+Altman&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=80&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Substance Abuse Treatment and the stages of Change: Selecting and Planning Interventions

Author: Stromwall, Layne K

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215389182?accountid=14667

Abstract: "Substance Abuse Treatment and the stages of Change: Selecting and Planning Interventions" by Gerard J. Connors et al is reviewed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Substance+Abuse+Treatment+and+the+stages+of+Change%3A+Selecting+and+Planning+Interventions&amp;rft.au=Stromwall%2C+Layne+K&amp;rft.aulast=Stromwall&amp;rft.aufirst=Layne&amp;rft.date=2003-04-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=94&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Nonfiction; Substance abuse treatment; Changes; Intervention

People: Connors, Gerard J

Title: Substance Abuse Treatment and the stages of Change: Selecting and Planning Interventions

Publication title: Affilia

Volume: 18

Issue: 1

Pages: 94-95

Number of pages: 2

Publication year: 2003

____________________________________________________________

The Supreme Court and women's rights: A new challenge

Author: Lens, Vicki

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388935?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the conservative activism of the Supreme Court under Chief Justice Rehnquist. Suggestions are made on how advocates, including social workers and their professional organizations, can advance the cause of social justice for women, given the current parameters of the Supreme Court. Strategies include shifting attention to other arenas, including federal and state legislatures and state courts; diluting the effects of the Court by delegitimating its decisions; and influencing the future composition of the Court.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Supreme+Court+and+women%27s+rights%3A+A+new+challenge&amp;rft.au=Lens%2C+Vicki&amp;rft.aulast=Lens&amp;rft.aufirst=Vicki&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=120&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

African American women at midlife: The relationship between spirituality and life satisfaction

Author: Starks, Saundra H; Hughey, Aaron W

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215401441?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this study, 147 African American women from six states were asked to complete the Adult Life Satisfaction Scale and the Black Women's Spirituality/Religiosity Measure (BWSRM), and in-depth interviews were conducted with 6 African American women. Although no significant difference was found among the ratings of life satisfaction and spirituality with respect to age or educational level, the women reported higher levels of religiosity than spirituality, which correlated significantly with life satisfaction. An analysis of a subscale of the BWSRM, however, found that the women reported significantly higher levels of spirituality than of religiosity. A moderate correlation was found between age and religiosity, and spirituality was found to be a critical variable that contributed to the life satisfaction of African American women at midlife regardless of age, income, or education.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=African+American+women+at+midlife%3A+The+relationship+between+spirituality+and+life+satisfaction&amp;rft.au=Starks%2C+Saundra+H%3BHughey%2C+Aaron+W&amp;rft.aulast=Starks&amp;rft.aufirst=Saundra&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=133&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Social work, young women, and femininity

Author: Barns, Angela

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215401344?accountid=14667

Abstract: As social work engages with feminism and postmodernism, the stringent dictates of femininity that underpin traditional social work with young women have been challenged. Social workers are asked to listen to young women's experiences of creating female subjectivities and to respect young women as the authors of their own gender identities. This article presents the findings of feminist interpretive research with six 14 to 15-year-old young women. Emphasizing the discourse of difference and its intersection with family, the mass media, peers, and fashion, the young women's stories alert social workers to the many ways in which young women negotiate, construct, and resist "the feminine."

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work%2C+young+women%2C+and+femininity&amp;rft.au=Barns%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Barns&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=148&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work%2C+young+women%2C+and+femininity&amp;rft.au=Barns%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Barns&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=148&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Exploring the diversity of women veterans' identity to improve the delivery of veterans' health services

Author: Huynh-Hohnbaum, Anh-Luu T; Damron-Rodriguez, JoAnn; Washington, Donna L; Villa, Valentine; Harada, Nancy

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390590?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study explored the domains of gender, ethnicity, and military association in a population of women veterans as these domains related to the women's access to and use of health care services and assessed barriers to the use of health services and suggestions for improving them. The study found that a significant proportion of the participants had experienced some form of gender discrimination in the military, through segregation or sexual harassment, and that their perceptions of the Veterans Administration health care system were framed by their military, ethnic/racial, and gender experiences.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+the+diversity+of+women+veterans%27+identity+to+improve+the+delivery+of+veterans%27+health+services&amp;rft.au=Huynh-Hohnbaum%2C+Anh-Luu+T%3BDamron-Rodriguez%2C+JoAnn%3BWashington%2C+Donna+L%3BVilla%2C+Valentine%3BHarada%2C+Nancy&amp;rft.aulast=Huynh-Hohnbaum&amp;rft.aufirst=Anh-Luu&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=165&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Social work response to domestic violence: Encouraging news from a new look

Author: Danis, Fran S

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215385147?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since the beginnings of the battered women's movement, the social work profession has been criticized for its inability to respond to victims of domestic abuse. This article reports on a survey of degreed and licensed professionals that finds that social workers may be doing better in their ability to assess and intervene with battered women. However, social workers are failing to use universal screening techniques to identify battered women and the women's children in their caseloads. Social work education must include a feminist analysis of domestic violence, along with feminist practice principles, to prepare professionals to address this prevalent problem better.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work+response+to+domestic+violence%3A+Encouraging+news+from+a+new+look&amp;rft.au=Danis%2C+Fran+S&amp;rft.aulast=Danis&amp;rft.aufirst=Fran&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=177&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Does gender matter? Male and female participation in social work classrooms

Author: Hyde, Cheryl A; Deal, Kathleen H

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215389007?accountid=14667

Abstract: On the basis of a survey of 264 participants and 8 follow-up focus groups with 44 total participants, this analysis considers why male and female students may censor themselves in classroom discussions and what solutions there are to this diminished participation. The survey revealed few statistically significant differences based on gender. However, when significant differences occurred, they reinforced stereotypical gender behavior among women. Gender differences were more pronounced in the focus groups with respect to both the interpretation of the survey data and communication styles. The female participants exhibited more caretaking and relational behaviors and tended to defer to authority, whereas the male participants were more assertive and concerned with how "oppressed" they were as men. Implications of these findings for social work education are offered.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Does+gender+matter%3F+Male+and+female+participation+in+social+work+classrooms&amp;rft.au=Hyde%2C+Cheryl+A%3BDeal%2C+Kathleen+H&amp;rft.aulast=Hyde&amp;rft.aufirst=Cheryl&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=192&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Negotiating the waves: Challenges of conducting in-prison and follow-up research with women

Author: O'Brien, Patricia; Bates, Robin

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215392578?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses the challenges, benefits, and lessons learned in the trenches of constructing a collaborative study with women who are in and transitioning out of prison. It describes five areas for negotiating different cultures in the research enterprise: the funding sponsor, the correctional institution and its multiple facilities, the university and its procedures for protecting human participants, the inmates/participants, and the communities to which the inmates return. Building trust and relationships across these multiple cultures is necessary to implement studies that can provide a foundation for developing restorative policies and practices.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Negotiating+the+waves%3A+Challenges+of+conducting+in-prison+and+follow-up+research+with+women&amp;rft.au=O%27Brien%2C+Patricia%3BBates%2C+Robin&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Brien&amp;rft.aufirst=Patricia&amp;rft.date=2003-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

"You have to do it for the people coming": Union organizing and the transformation of immigrant women workers

Author: Susan Kerr Chandler; Jones, Jill

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388793?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study explored the experiences of a group of women who migrated to the United States from Mexico and Central America, found employment in Nevada casinos, and eventually became active in the Hotel Employees, Restaurant Employees Union. Their stories chronicle both their journey and their transformation: the gradual giving way of initial hopelessness and despair to a sense of personal and collective political power. This study is part of a larger study of the experience of women casino workers in the context of economic globalization.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22You+have+to+do+it+for+the+people+coming%22%3A+Union+organizing+and+the+transformation+of+immigrant+women+workers&amp;rft.au=Susan+Kerr+Chandler%3BJones%2C+Jill&amp;rft.aulast=Susan+Kerr+Chandler&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2003-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=254&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

A social justice model for clinical social work practice

Author: Parker, Lynn

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384756?accountid=14667

Abstract: Feminists have long challenged social workers to address issues of equity and justice in clinical practice. This article presents a case study of a family services program, the Institute for Family Services (IFS), whose intention is to do just that. At IFS, power issues are central to all therapeutic conversations and to the structure of the program. Findings from interviews with staff members and clients and observation of the program illustrate how the program sets out to reveal and influence issues of power, privilege, and oppression. Fundamental and unique to this model are the use of same-gender therapy groups, social education, and community sponsors.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=A+social+justice+model+for+clinical+social+work+practice&amp;rft.au=Parker%2C+Lynn&amp;rft.aulast=Parker&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynn&amp;rft.date=2003-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=272&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=A+social+justice+model+for+clinical+social+work+practice&amp;rft.au=Parker%2C+Lynn&amp;rft.aulast=Parker&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynn&amp;rft.date=2003-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=272&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Developing empowerment and leadership: The case of immigrant women in Israel

Author: Itzhaky, Haya

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395952?accountid=14667

Abstract: To help low-income women immigrants to Israel from Ethiopia and the former Soviet Union adapt, an interdisciplinary team prepared and conducted a community program whose goals were to empower the women and help them to become involved in the community and to become leaders. The outcomes of the project were favorable. All the women became involved in community activities, were empowered, and developed their leadership abilities and a sense of community belonging. Only their sense of policy control did not undergo any significant change.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+empowerment+and+leadership%3A+The+case+of+immigrant+women+in+Israel&amp;rft.au=Itzhaky%2C+Haya&amp;rft.aulast=Itzhaky&amp;rft.aufirst=Haya&amp;rft.date=2003-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=289&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Providing comprehensive case management services to urban women with HIV/AIDS and their families

Author: Parrish, Margarete; Burry, Caroline; Pabst, Mary S

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215392440?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women continue to be disproportionately affected with HIV. Women with HIV/AIDS are also more likely than their male counterparts to be single heads of households and primary providers for their children. Social workers are ideally suited to recognize the psychosocial complexities that HIV/AIDS entails for women and how such circumstances can interfere with medical management and meeting children's needs. This article discusses the literature relevant to women with HIV/AIDS and case management and describes a community-based case management program that was designed to serve urban women with newly diagnosed or newly disclosed cases of HIV/AIDS and their families.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Providing+comprehensive+case+management+services+to+urban+women+with+HIV%2FAIDS+and+their+families&amp;rft.au=Parrish%2C+Margarete%3BBurry%2C+Caroline%3BPabst%2C+Mary+S&amp;rft.aulast=Parrish&amp;rft.aufirst=Margarete&amp;rft.date=2003-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=302&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Feeling poor: The felt experience of low-income lone mothers

Author: McIntyre, Lynn; Officer, Suzanne; Robinson, Lynne M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384818?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes what it means to feel poor from the perspective of low-income lone mothers. The construct of feeling poor is complex and multifaceted for these mothers, whose common behaviors include self-sacrifice and coping. The authors identify 10 feeling domains for these mothers: feeling deprived, righteous, the need for occupational choice, relatively better positioned than others, the need to manage the appearance of poverty, judged/degraded, guilty, isolated, dependent, and despondent.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Feeling+poor%3A+The+felt+experience+of+low-income+lone+mothers&amp;rft.au=McIntyre%2C+Lynn%3BOfficer%2C+Suzanne%3BRobinson%2C+Lynne+M&amp;rft.aulast=McIntyre&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynn&amp;rft.date=2003-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=316&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Translating principles into practice: Implementing the feminist and strengths perspectives in work with battered women

Author: Black, Carolyn J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395764?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the narratives of battered women to determine whether court advocates used principles of the feminist and strengths perspectives to assist the women in obtaining protective orders and devising safety plans. The results indicated that advocates were using principles of these perspectives. Advocates uncovered women's strengths, often reinforcing the steps the women had taken to effect positive change in their lives, and gave the women information on resources. Most of the women were satisfied with the services and believed that the advocates showed concern about their plight. Taking time to listen was cited as a major aspect of that display of concern.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Translating+principles+into+practice%3A+Implementing+the+feminist+and+strengths+perspectives+in+work+with+battered+women&amp;rft.au=Black%2C+Carolyn+J&amp;rft.aulast=Black&amp;rft.aufirst=Carolyn&amp;rft.date=2003-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=332&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Self-Harm Narratives of Urban and Suburban Young Women

Author: Abrams, Laura S1; Gordon, Anne L1 School of Social Work, University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, labrams@che.umn.edu.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/811224551?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study explored the motivations, meanings, functions, and consequences of self-harm for young women in urban and suburban contexts. It found that all 6 participants deliberately harmed themselves in response to traumas, family stress, and relationship problems. However, the suburban girls connected their self-harm behaviors to an overall sense of despondency, whereas the urban girls attributed these to release of unresolved anger. Key differences between the groups also emerged in the functions and consequences of their self-harm behaviors. These findings can increase social workers' capacity to respond to intentional self-injury among ethnically and socioeconomically diverse populations of young women.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Self-Harm+Narratives+of+Urban+and+Suburban+Young+Women&amp;rft.au=Abrams%2C+Laura+S%3BGordon%2C+Anne+L&amp;rft.aulast=Abrams&amp;rft.aufirst=Laura&amp;rft.date=2003-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=429&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109903257668

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Self-Harm+Narratives+of+Urban+and+Suburban+Young+Women&amp;rft.au=Abrams%2C+Laura+S%3BGordon%2C+Anne+L&amp;rft.aulast=Abrams&amp;rft.aufirst=Laura&amp;rft.date=2003-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=429&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109903257668

____________________________________________________________

Strange bedfellows: Feminist advocates and U.S. Marines working to end violence

Author: Kanuha, Valli Kalei; Erwin, Patricia; Pence, Ellen

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390332?accountid=14667

Abstract: The incidence of intimate partner abuse among couples in the military, as throughout all social life, has been well documented. In the early 1990s, there were a number of dramatic domestic-violence-related cases, including homicides of military wives. In response, the U.S. Marines partnered with an advocacy-based domestic violence organization to implement a coordinated community response to domestic violence throughout the U.S. Marine Corps. This article presents a case study describing the processes, activities, policies, accomplishments, and challenges of the project from 1992 to 1998.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Strange+bedfellows%3A+Feminist+advocates+and+U.S.+Marines+working+to+end+violence&amp;rft.au=Kanuha%2C+Valli+Kalei%3BErwin%2C+Patricia%3BPence%2C+Ellen&amp;rft.aulast=Kanuha&amp;rft.aufirst=Valli&amp;rft.date=2004-12-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=358&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Strange+bedfellows%3A+Feminist+advocates+and+U.S.+Marines+working+to+end+violence&amp;rft.au=Kanuha%2C+Valli+Kalei%3BErwin%2C+Patricia%3BPence%2C+Ellen&amp;rft.aulast=Kanuha&amp;rft.aufirst=Valli&amp;rft.date=2004-12-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=358&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Addressing the problem of domestic violence: How far have we come?

Author: Pyles, Loretta; Postmus, Judy L

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390281?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social work profession has a complex and arguably problematic history in relation to the problem of domestic violence. Through a review of abstracts of social work articles published from 1985 to 2000, the authors sought to determine whether anything has changed since Davis's (1987) seminal study regarding the way in which the profession addresses the problem of domestic violence. The findings indicate that although researchers have done a good job of listening to the voices of battered women, there has been scant theorizing in the literature about the sexist origins of the problem.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Addressing+the+problem+of+domestic+violence%3A+How+far+have+we+come%3F&amp;rft.au=Pyles%2C+Loretta%3BPostmus%2C+Judy+L&amp;rft.aulast=Pyles&amp;rft.aufirst=Loretta&amp;rft.date=2004-12-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=376&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

War rape: New conceptualizations and responses

Author: Farwell, Nancy

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215380057?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents new conceptualizations of war rape in international law and defines rape as a weapon and strategy of war. It also outlines the intersections of gender, patriarchy, militarism, and ethnic, religious, and political identities that fuel war rape as part of a continuum of violence against women. Local and transnational examples of women's responses to war rape demonstrate their importance to survivors, practitioners, and policy makers who seek to address its causes and effects. Finally, the article challenges feminist social workers to address the dynamics of war rape within the complex nexus of policies that fuel conflict.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=War+rape%3A+New+conceptualizations+and+responses&amp;rft.au=Farwell%2C+Nancy&amp;rft.aulast=Farwell&amp;rft.aufirst=Nancy&amp;rft.date=2004-12-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=389&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Crone songs: Voices of lesbian elders on aging in a rural environment

Author: Comerford, Susan A; M Maxwell Henson-Stroud; Corbett Sionainn; Wheeler, Elizabeth

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215400975?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on a qualitative study with 15 lesbian elders that explored their perceptions of aging in Vermont. Three broad themes were identified as having an impact on the aging process of these lesbian women: self-reliance mediated by interdependence, the state as context, and social supports. Implications for social work education and practice are presented.

____________________________________________________________

Women who die young: The cumulative disadvantage of race

Author: Caputo, Richard K

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395407?accountid=14667

Abstract: The current study used cumulative disadvantage theory to assess the relative influence of race on mortality among 2,288 young women. The findings indicate that race is a robust predictor of women's mortality at young ages even when human, social, personal, institutional, and community capital are accounted for. They suggest that feminists and other advocates for social justice who seek to create more equitable life-course outcomes in the society at large should not ignore race when they consider women's issues.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Women+who+die+young%3A+The+cumulative+disadvantage+of+race&amp;rft.au=Caputo%2C+Richard+K&amp;rft.aulast=Caputo&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=10&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Motherhood in a time of terror: Subjective experiences and responses of Israeli mothers

Author: Dekel, Rachel

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215386573?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of the study was to explore the subjective experience of being a mother in an extreme period of terror and uncertainty. Eleven Israeli mothers who had one to three children, ranging in age from 8 months to 12 years, participated in a focus group. A content analysis revealed five main concerns: physical protection, emotional protection, transmission of ideology, creation of normalcy and routine, and the question of what will happen to the children if the mothers are killed in a terror attack. The discussion examines the uniqueness and similarities of the findings to other theoretical and empirical works on motherhood.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Motherhood+in+a+time+of+terror%3A+Subjective+experiences+and+responses+of+Israeli+mothers&amp;rft.au=Dekel%2C+Rachel&amp;rft.aulast=Dekel&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachel&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=24&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Education and training for low-income women: An elusive goal

Author: Bok, Marcia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215380155?accountid=14667

Abstract: Welfare reform has generally denied poor women access to effective education and training that could lead to economic independence. Instead, a work-first approach prevails. As the public safety net is removed and education and training are not provided, welfare reform reinforces the economic and social status quo. This article addresses barriers to education and training along a continuum of possible educational opportunities and argues that education and skills training for low-income women, especially poor women of color, are moral and economic imperatives. Current affirmative action successes can provide guidance for increasing access to education and training for poor women.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Education+and+training+for+low-income+women%3A+An+elusive+goal&amp;rft.au=Bok%2C+Marcia&amp;rft.aulast=Bok&amp;rft.aufirst=Marcia&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=39&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The impact of priest sexual abuse: Female survivors' narratives

Author: Katherine van Wormer; Berns, Lois

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215392167?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the effect of priests'sexual abuse on victimized girls and young women. The data were obtained from in-depth interviews with women who were seeking help years after the violation. The results revealed the following themes: the loss of innocence, a period of self-blame, the loss of religious faith, immense pressure to maintain silence, recognition of the imbalance of power, and healing through out-side help. The contribution of the principles of restorative justice to victims'healing is described.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+impact+of+priest+sexual+abuse%3A+Female+survivors%27+narratives&amp;rft.au=Katherine+van+Wormer%3BBerns%2C+Lois&amp;rft.aulast=Katherine+van+Wormer&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=53&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Racial and ethnic identity development in white mothers of biracial, black-white children

Author: O'Donoghue, Margaret

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215392669?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on a qualitative research study of the racial and ethnic identity of 11 White mothers who were married to Black (specifically African American) men and were raising biracial children. The uniqueness of these women's lives, as Whites with an intimate knowledge of the Black experience, makes it difficult to place them within the levels described by current models of racial identity. Through their parenting of biracial children, the mothers had come to a greater sense of their own racial identity and to recognize White privilege and their own White identity. Their specific ethnic identity, as ethnic Whites, has not been passed on to their children.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Racial+and+ethnic+identity+development+in+white+mothers+of+biracial%2C+black-white+children&amp;rft.au=O%27Donoghue%2C+Margaret&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Donoghue&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=68&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The theory of mindful space: Identifying, understanding, and preventing violence

Author: Burlae, krista K

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388217?accountid=14667

Abstract: Usually, involved definitions of violence toward women are within such contexts as domestic violence or theories of rape. The theory of mindful space succinctly defines violence as it occurs naturally and as it occurs as an imbalance of nature. Based on concepts of space and the life cycle (literal and symbolic processes of birth and death), this theory suggests a myriad of cues for women to notice in the initial and enduring stages of a violent experience. Using these cues, women may be able to identify and avoid violence long before it becomes destructive.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+theory+of+mindful+space%3A+Identifying%2C+understanding%2C+and+preventing+violence&amp;rft.au=Burlae%2C+krista+K&amp;rft.aulast=Burlae&amp;rft.aufirst=krista&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=85&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+theory+of+mindful+space%3A+Identifying%2C+understanding%2C+and+preventing+violence&amp;rft.au=Burlae%2C+krista+K&amp;rft.aulast=Burlae&amp;rft.aufirst=krista&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=85&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Maryann Mahaffey: An activist for all seasons

Author: Sarri, Rosemary

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390388?accountid=14667

Abstract: Because of her vivaciousness, motivation, and sincerity, it seems impossible to believe that Maryann Mahaffey has contributed as a social worker, author, educator, volunteer, and political leader at the local, state, national and international levels for nearly 60 years and still maintains her deep commitment to critical social issues. She is one of the key political leaders of Detroit and is nationally recognized for her work with municipal governments, as well as in social work.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Maryann+Mahaffey%3A+An+activist+for+all+seasons&amp;rft.au=Sarri%2C+Rosemary&amp;rft.aulast=Sarri&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosemary&amp;rft.date=2004-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=99&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Mentoring in the careers of African American women in social work education

Author: Simon, Cassandra E; Bowles, Dorcas D; King, Shirley W; Roff, Lucinda L

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388168?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports the findings of a study that examined the role of mentoring in the careers of African American women in the administration of social work education. A focus of the study was the ways in which race and gender influence mentoring experiences. The findings suggest that although the participants were successful in their careers, mentoring opportunities were not a part of their early career experiences. They also indicate that race and gender play important roles in the type of mentoring experienced by African American women in social work academia. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Mentoring+in+the+careers+of+African+American+women+in+social+work+education&amp;rft.au=Simon%2C+Cassandra+E%3BBowles%2C+Dorcas+D%3BKing%2C+Shirley+W%3BRoff%2C+Lucinda+L&amp;rft.aulast=Simon&amp;rft.aufirst=Cassandra&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=134&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Life changing: The experience of rape-crisis work

Author: Clemans, Shantih E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215397650?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sexual violence has been studied extensively in the social work literature. However, the experiences of social workers in organizations that serve clients who are victims of sexual violence have been given limited attention. This article presents the findings of a qualitative study that explored the experiences of 21 women employees of rape-crisis programs. The findings suggest that social work with such clients presented the workers with a host of emotional and existential challenges, such as increased feelings of vulnerability as women, diminished trust in others, and questioning the overall goodness of society. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Life+changing%3A+The+experience+of+rape-crisis+work&amp;rft.au=Clemans%2C+Shantih+E&amp;rft.aulast=Clemans&amp;rft.aufirst=Shantih&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=146&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Relationship constellations and dynamics of low-income rural mothers

Author: Kohler, Julie K; Anderson, Elaine A; Oravecz, Linda; Braun, Bonnie

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215380114?accountid=14667

Abstract: To address the policy debate surrounding the use of funds from Temporary Assistance to Needy Families for marriage-promotion activities, this article profiles the nature of low-income rural mothers' relationships with their partners and the nonresidential fathers of their children. It presents the results of interviews with 35 low income mothers from two rural Maryland counties. Although the analyses revealed that the presence of a male partner was not related to a mother's economic or emotional well-being, other sources of social support buffered mothers against their economic challenges. The authors conclude that social workers should integrate informal family support into their service delivery plans and that policy makers need to consider alternatives to fostering economic self-sufficiency among rural low-income populations. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Relationship+constellations+and+dynamics+of+low-income+rural+mothers&amp;rft.au=Kohler%2C+Julie+K%3BAnderson%2C+Elaine+A%3BOravecz%2C+Linda%3BBraun%2C+Bonnie&amp;rft.aulast=Kohler&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=160&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Social support and functioning of nuclear families headed by lesbian couples

Author: Speziale, Bette; Gopalakrishna, Veena

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395309?accountid=14667

Abstract: Changes in social and sexual mores in the latter part of the 20th century have become apparent in the diverse families who live openly in communities throughout the United States. Among these diverse family systems is the nuclear family that is headed by a lesbian couple. The findings of predominantly qualitative research studies on the social support and functioning of this increasingly visible family form have identified the needs of these nontraditional nuclear families. This article presents an overview of the empirical findings about nuclear families that are headed by lesbian couples. Moreover, it discusses the implications of the findings for empowering interventions with, and social work advocacy for, lesbian mothers, co-mothers,and their children. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Social+support+and+functioning+of+nuclear+families+headed+by+lesbian+couples&amp;rft.au=Speziale%2C+Bette%3BGopalakrishna%2C+Veena&amp;rft.aulast=Speziale&amp;rft.aufirst=Bette&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=174&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Campus-based women's centers: A review of problems and practices

Author: Kasper, Barbara

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395363?accountid=14667

Abstract: Campus-based women's centers can provide a wealth of resources to feminist social workers, yet little has been written about their structure and practices. This article reports on a study of 75 campus-based women's centers in the United States during academic year 1999-2000. Responses to the portions of the survey that were devoted to the programs of these centers are summarized, with particular attention to the various means of fostering the participation of specific populations on campus. Barriers to the successful operation of women's centers that were identified by the respondents are also discussed. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Campus-based+women%27s+centers%3A+A+review+of+problems+and+practices&amp;rft.au=Kasper%2C+Barbara&amp;rft.aulast=Kasper&amp;rft.aufirst=Barbara&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=185&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Work and social support: Social workers' assessments of male and female clients' problems and needs

Author: Kullberg, Christian

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215392569?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigated how social workers assess single mothers' and fathers' needs in the areas of paid work and social support. It found that social workers conform to gender "heteronormative" expectations. A father's problems are assessed as being more closely linked to paid work than are a mother's, whereas a mother's problems are assessed as being related to difficulties in the area of social networks. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Work+and+social+support%3A+Social+workers%27+assessments+of+male+and+female+clients%27+problems+and+needs&amp;rft.au=Kullberg%2C+Christian&amp;rft.aulast=Kullberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Christian&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=199&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Lifetime abuse and mental health distress among English-speaking Latinas

Author: Ramos, Blanca M; Carlson, Bonnie E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388557?accountid=14667

Abstract: Domestic violence has adverse consequences on the mental health of abused women, including Latinas, who face stressors that are associated with oppression, resettlement, and minority status, which increase their risk of abuse and its psychological distress. This article presents a descriptive study of lifetime abuse (seven types of childhood abuse and abuse by adult partners) and mental health in a small sample of English-speaking Latinas. Depression, anxiety, and somatization were studied in relation to lifetime abuse. The findings revealed that recent emotional abuse was associated with distress, which was manifested in anxiety, and that childhood abuse elevated the risk of victimization in adulthood. Implications for feminist social work practice are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Lifetime+abuse+and+mental+health+distress+among+English-speaking+Latinas&amp;rft.au=Ramos%2C+Blanca+M%3BCarlson%2C+Bonnie+E&amp;rft.aulast=Ramos&amp;rft.aufirst=Blanca&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=239&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Lifetime+abuse+and+mental+health+distress+among+English-speaking+Latinas&amp;rft.au=Ramos%2C+Blanca+M%3BCarlson%2C+Bonnie+E&amp;rft.aulast=Ramos&amp;rft.aufirst=Blanca&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=239&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

African American reformers' mission: Caring for our girls and women

Author: Carlton-LaNey, Iris; Hodges, Vanessa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215398263?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article focuses on the mechanisms that African American women used during the Progressive Era to meet the needs of young African American women and girls. It identifies some of the early reform women and describes the girls and women who were the recipients of their beneficence. Attention is also given to specific strategies that were implemented by service organizations and groups, such as women's clubs, sororities, schools, and settlement houses.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=African+American+reformers%27+mission%3A+Caring+for+our+girls+and+women&amp;rft.au=Carlton-LaNey%2C+Iris%3BHodges%2C+Vanessa&amp;rft.aulast=Carlton-LaNey&amp;rft.aufirst=Iris&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

"Family violence": The language of legitimacy

Author: Hammons, Stacy A

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395713?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examinations of social movements have typically overlooked the organizational context of social-movement agencies as well as the role of agency employees in shaping the larger movement. This study explored meso-and micro-level forces that affect the battered women's movement, as found in one particular women's shelter. The findings suggest that although the larger social movement may encourage the examination of battering from a systemic perspective, shelter workers adopt a more narrow, psychological interpretation. Shelter workers adopt this perspective because of the socialization that occurs within the shelter context itself, which employees then replicate to be seen as competent.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22Family+violence%22%3A+The+language+of+legitimacy&amp;rft.au=Hammons%2C+Stacy+A&amp;rft.aulast=Hammons&amp;rft.aufirst=Stacy&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=273&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22Family+violence%22%3A+The+language+of+legitimacy&amp;rft.au=Hammons%2C+Stacy+A&amp;rft.aulast=Hammons&amp;rft.aufirst=Stacy&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=273&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Paternalistic regulation of women: Exploring punitive sanctions in Temporary Assistance to Needy Families

Author: Rainford, William C

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384622?accountid=14667

Abstract: U.S. welfare policy coerces low-income women into low-wage jobs by imposing punitive sanctions for not working, despite the lack of supporting evidence that sanctions are effective. This qualitative study explored whether sanctions compel compliance, whether there are unintended consequences of sanctions, and what causes noncompliance. The findings indicate that noncompliance is not always chosen but results from insurmountable barriers. Furthermore, sanctions may create a communication disconnect between clients and the welfare agency, rendering the clients further entrenched in poverty and dependence. Implications for research and policy are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Paternalistic+regulation+of+women%3A+Exploring+punitive+sanctions+in+Temporary+Assistance+to+Needy+Families&amp;rft.au=Rainford%2C+William+C&amp;rft.aulast=Rainford&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=289&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Paternalistic+regulation+of+women%3A+Exploring+punitive+sanctions+in+Temporary+Assistance+to+Needy+Families&amp;rft.au=Rainford%2C+William+C&amp;rft.aulast=Rainford&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=289&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Domestic violence in the Orthodox Jewish home: A value-sensitive approach to recovery

Author: Grodner, Elana; Sweifach, Jay

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395754?accountid=14667

Abstract: Domestic violence, a once-hidden problem in the Orthodox Jewish community, is now acknowledged to occur in Orthodox Jewish families. Because this problem was not affirmed earlier, effective therapeutic techniques for working with battered Orthodox women have only recently begun to emerge. This article highlights one therapeutic technique - the value-sensitive approach - which uses ethnoculturalreligious factors as part of the therapeutic process and has generated positive results in working with battered Orthodox women.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Domestic+violence+in+the+Orthodox+Jewish+home%3A+A+value-sensitive+approach+to+recovery&amp;rft.au=Grodner%2C+Elana%3BSweifach%2C+Jay&amp;rft.aulast=Grodner&amp;rft.aufirst=Elana&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=305&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Dignity, financial literacy, and food, glorious food! The legacy of Kathy Goldman

Author: Mills, Jean

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215386518?accountid=14667

Abstract: On May 1, 2003, at St. Peter's Church in New York City, Kathy Goldman was paid tribute for her more than 20 years of service as the founder and executive director of the Community Food Resource Center. Goldman started the CRFC in 1980 with a $6,000 grant for a school breakfast campaign.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Dignity%2C+financial+literacy%2C+and+food%2C+glorious+food%21+The+legacy+of+Kathy+Goldman&amp;rft.au=Mills%2C+Jean&amp;rft.aulast=Mills&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean&amp;rft.date=2004-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=317&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
