____________________________________________________________

Balancing Power Through Community Building: Setting the Research Agenda on Violence Against Women

Author: Bell, Holly1; Busch, Noel Bridget; Heffron, Laurie Cook; White, Barbara; Angelelli, Maria Jose; Rivaux, Stephanie1 Center for Social Work Research at the School of Social Work, University of Texas at Austin (1 University Station, D3500, Austin, TX 78712-0359) and Institute on Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault, hbell@mail.utexas.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/811291395?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a feminist model for collaboration by researchers, practitioners, and survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault that focuses on balancing power and building community. Thirty-eight university researchers, survivors, and practitioners met to define and prioritize a research agenda on domestic violence and sexual assault, plan for continued collaboration, and evaluate the community-building process. This article presents data from focus groups, written evaluations, and researcher-participant observations that indicated the research topics that the participants ranked as the most important or useful to them and outlines the participants' concerns about and suggestions for ongoing collaboration.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Balancing+Power+Through+Community+Building%3A+Setting+the+Research+Agenda+on+Violence+Against+Women&amp;rft.au=Bell%2C+Holly%3BBusch%2C+Noel+Bridget%3BHeffron%2C+Laurie+Cook%3BWhite%2C+Barbara%3BAngelelli%2C+Maria+Jose%3BRivaux%2C+Stephanie&amp;rft.aulast=Bell&amp;rft.aufirst=Holly&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=404&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109904268871

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Balancing+Power+Through+Community+Building%3A+Setting+the+Research+Agenda+on+Violence+Against+Women&amp;rft.au=Bell%2C+Holly%3BBusch%2C+Noel+Bridget%3BHeffron%2C+Laurie+Cook%3BWhite%2C+Barbara%3BAngelelli%2C+Maria+Jose%3BRivaux%2C+Stephanie&amp;rft.aulast=Bell&amp;rft.aufirst=Holly&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=404&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109904268871

____________________________________________________________

Predicting Gender-Role Attitudes Among Mothers and Their Adolescent Daughters in Israel

Author: Kulik, Liat11 School of Social Work, Bar Ilan University, Ramat Gan, Israel, kulikl@mail.biu.ac.il

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/811224640?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study compared predictors of gender-role attitudes among 60 mothers and their 60 adolescent daughters in Israel. Two sets of predictors were studied-background variables (education, religiosity, age, ethnicity, family income, and mother's length of marriage) and personality traits (self-esteem and tolerance for ambiguity). Significant correlations were found between the mothers' and daughters' gender-role attitudes. Among the mothers, the main background predictors were religiosity, ethnicity, and education, and the main personality predictor was self-esteem. Among the daughters, the main predictors were religiosity, mothers' length of marriage, and self-esteem. The variables were better predictors for the mothers than for the daughters.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Predicting+Gender-Role+Attitudes+Among+Mothers+and+Their+Adolescent+Daughters+in+Israel&amp;rft.au=Kulik%2C+Liat&amp;rft.aulast=Kulik&amp;rft.aufirst=Liat&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=437&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109904268930

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Predicting+Gender-Role+Attitudes+Among+Mothers+and+Their+Adolescent+Daughters+in+Israel&amp;rft.au=Kulik%2C+Liat&amp;rft.aulast=Kulik&amp;rft.aufirst=Liat&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=437&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109904268930

In the Shadow of Race: Immigrant Status and Mental Health

Author: Kurz, Brenda; Barris, Malcolm; Cournoyer, David

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390073?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explored the relative usefulness of measures of race, ethnicity, and acculturation in understanding the mental health of an ethnically diverse group of low-income women. The 194 women who were enrolled in the Women, Infant and Child program showed no racial/ethnic variation in the prevalence of mental health symptoms and a general mental health syndrome, as measured by the PrimeMD-PHQ screening tool. However, immigrants or migrants were less likely than were natives to report symptoms of depression and distress. Speaking primarily a language other than English was associated with symptoms of distress. The findings suggest that for treatment and program planning for low-income women, racial/ethnic designations may be less useful than may the more direct measures of the cultural differences they presume to reflect.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=In+the+Shadow+of+Race%3A+Immigrant+Status+and+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Kurz%2C+Brenda%3BBarris%2C+Malcolm%3BCournoyer%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Kurz&amp;rft.aufirst=Brenda&amp;rft.date=2005-12-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=434&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=In+the+Shadow+of+Race%3A+Immigrant+Status+and+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Kurz%2C+Brenda%3BBarris%2C+Malcolm%3BCournoyer%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Kurz&amp;rft.aufirst=Brenda&amp;rft.date=2005-12-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=434&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Lady Boards of Managers: Subjugated Legacies of Governance and Administration

Author: Netting, F Ellen; O'Connor, Mary Katherine

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215394967?accountid=14667

Abstract: Three traditions of women's organizations emerged in the 1800s: benevolence, reform, and rights. This article focuses primarily on women who founded the forerunners of today's nonprofit health and human service agencies. Using Richmond, Virginia, as an example, it draws from historical documents, as well as the literature, to reframe the importance of what Lady Boards of Managers did in shaping the governance and administration of early human service organizations. Of particular importance is the invisibility of their actions, which were extraordinary for the times in which they lived, in the theories and practice models that drive current macro-social work practice.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Lady+Boards+of+Managers%3A+Subjugated+Legacies+of+Governance+and+Administration&amp;rft.au=Netting%2C+F+Ellen%3BO%27Connor%2C+Mary+Katherine&amp;rft.aulast=Netting&amp;rft.aufirst=F&amp;rft.date=2005-12-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=448&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Trained Volunteers as Mental Health Counselors: Addressing the Enormous Shortage of Trained Counselors

Author: Wilson, Ann M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384297?accountid=14667

Abstract: The spirit of service and volunteering in nonprofit and community-based organizations has been a staple of American life for hundreds of years. Although courts have referred clients to mental health agencies since the end of the 19th century, volunteers who are trained mental health counselors are a phenomenon that agencies have only recently used to address both court-ordered and other referrals. This article highlights one successful countywide model that can be replicated nationwide and can be a powerful tool in any community.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Trained+Volunteers+as+Mental+Health+Counselors%3A+Addressing+the+Enormous+Shortage+of+Trained+Counselors&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+Ann+M&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2005-12-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=476&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Women, love, and intimacy "gone wrong": Fire, wind, and ice

Author: Fraser, Heather

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395609?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although questions about why so many women "love to love" and why some stay with abusive lovers may seem cliched, they are questions over which many people still muse. Using a collage of ideas drawn from a wide range of sources, including 83 narrative feminist interviews that were conducted from 2000 to 2004, I respond to these questions, trying to show some of the inducements that are made to women to love others. The simulated diary entries of one (composite) woman suggest that as many women enter monogamous coupledom, there are unexpected (but all too common) problems of intimacy. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Women%2C+love%2C+and+intimacy+%22gone+wrong%22%3A+Fire%2C+wind%2C+and+ice&amp;rft.au=Fraser%2C+Heather&amp;rft.aulast=Fraser&amp;rft.aufirst=Heather&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=10&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Maggie Lena Walker and African American community development

Author: Schiele, Jerome H; M Sebrena Jackson; Colita Nichols Fairfax

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215397595?accountid=14667

Abstract: One of the unsung heroines of the African American tradition of community development is Maggie Lena Walker. Walker was the first woman in the United States to establish a bank that still exists today. She also started a merchandise department store, operated a newspaper, and was a prominent leader in a major African American mutual aid organization--the Independent Order of St. Luke. This article discusses Walker's community development contributions and examines their relevance for contemporary community practice with African Americans. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Maggie+Lena+Walker+and+African+American+community+development&amp;rft.au=Schiele%2C+Jerome+H%3BM+Sebrena+Jackson%3BColita+Nichols+Fairfax&amp;rft.aulast=Schiele&amp;rft.aufirst=Jerome&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Maggie+Lena+Walker+and+African+American+community+development&amp;rft.au=Schiele%2C+Jerome+H%3BM+Sebrena+Jackson%3BColita+Nichols+Fairfax&amp;rft.aulast=Schiele&amp;rft.aufirst=Jerome&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Battered women in shelters: Internal resources, well-being, and integration

Author: Itzhaky, Haya; Anat Ben Porat

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388522?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines changes in internal resources (empowerment and self-esteem), well-being (life satisfaction and hope), and integration in the shelter (participation and commitment) experienced by women at domestic violence shelters in Israel. The participants were compared at two points in time--1 week and 3 months after their arrival at the shelter. Small but significant differences were found in all measures, except those concerning participation in and commitment to the shelter and one of the empowerment components--the ability to accept help and take advantage of professional services. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Battered+women+in+shelters%3A+Internal+resources%2C+well-being%2C+and+integration&amp;rft.au=Itzhaky%2C+Haya%3BAnat+Ben+Porat&amp;rft.aulast=Itzhaky&amp;rft.aufirst=Haya&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=39&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Gender-specific services in the juvenile justice system: A critical examination

Author: Goodkind, Sara

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215398166?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reviews the literature on gender-specific services for girls in the juvenile justice system. Drawing on feminist theorizing, it offers four critiques: (a) that the increasing involvement of girls in the system is taken as a real indicator of greater crime and delinquency; (b) that an essentialized notion of gender is used; (c) that the problem is located in the individual, to the exclusion of solutions that focus on system/structural changes; and (d) that a focus on girls' victimization obscures girls' agency and perpetuates girls' continued punishment for behaviors that are more acceptable among boys. The article concludes by proposing a framework for rethinking gender in the design and delivery of services within and outside the juvenile justice system. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Gender-specific+services+in+the+juvenile+justice+system%3A+A+critical+examination&amp;rft.au=Goodkind%2C+Sara&amp;rft.aulast=Goodkind&amp;rft.aufirst=Sara&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=52&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Gender-specific+services+in+the+juvenile+justice+system%3A+A+critical+examination&amp;rft.au=Goodkind%2C+Sara&amp;rft.aulast=Goodkind&amp;rft.aufirst=Sara&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=52&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Progress for women faculty in social work academia

Author: Sunday Di Palma

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215386413?accountid=14667

Abstract: The literature on women's progress in various disciplines in U.S. higher education, including social work academia, has generally concluded that women continue to be discriminated against. This article presents a study of data from 1974 to 2000 to evaluate this claim. I conclude that although women continue to be under-represented on the faculties of U.S. colleges and universities across disciplines, women social work faculty have made great progress. Possible reasons for these findings are considered. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Progress+for+women+faculty+in+social+work+academia&amp;rft.au=Sunday+Di+Palma&amp;rft.aulast=Sunday+Di+Palma&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Reading a poor woman's life: Issues and dilemmas

Author: Krumer-Nevo, Michal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215400908?accountid=14667

Abstract: Listening to the voices of poor women is a major goal of feminists who are dealing with the subject of poverty; however, its implementation is far from simple. Problems of power and ethics are enmeshed with the question of how to understand these voices and how to make them heard without exploiting or distorting them. This article counters these issues in presenting a feminist reading of Miriam--a woman living in poverty and social deprivation. The feminist reading of the story sheds light on Miriam's limited opportunities, the nature of her difficulties, and her struggle. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Reading+a+poor+woman%27s+life%3A+Issues+and+dilemmas&amp;rft.au=Krumer-Nevo%2C+Michal&amp;rft.aulast=Krumer-Nevo&amp;rft.aufirst=Michal&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Katherine Kendall: A social work institution

Author: Brandwein, Ruth A

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215392520?accountid=14667

Abstract: Katherine Kendall has been one of the leaders in social work education and especially international social welfare for more than 50 years. She was a founder of the Council of Social Work Education and later became its Executive Director. She became the first salaried secretary-general of the International Association of Schools of Social Work in 1972. Now, older than 90 years, she is still active as a published author and is often an invited speaker at national and international conferences. Her early career and personal decisions reflect feminist values in the context of the Depression Era, World War II, and the postwar period. She is a powerful role model for women today and especially for active, positive aging. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Katherine+Kendall%3A+A+social+work+institution&amp;rft.au=Brandwein%2C+Ruth+A&amp;rft.aulast=Brandwein&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2005-04-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=103&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Combining Caregiving and Career: Experiences of Social Work Faculty

Author: Young, Diane S; Holley, Lynn C

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390178?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the findings from a survey of 75 social work faculty with doctoral degrees about the family and caregiving factors that affected their career decisions and experiences. Qualitative analyses indicated that both the women and the men had family- and caregiving-related concerns that pertained primarily to the regular care of children but also to the care of individuals with disabilities and of frail elders. Forty-seven percent of the participants described helpful family-related university policies, and 28% described institutional barriers to achieving their career goals. Suggestions for creating family-friendly institutions are presented. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Combining+Caregiving+and+Career%3A+Experiences+of+Social+Work+Faculty&amp;rft.au=Young%2C+Diane+S%3BHolley%2C+Lynn+C&amp;rft.aulast=Young&amp;rft.aufirst=Diane&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=136&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Contribution of the Sisters of Mercy to the Development of Social Welfare

Author: Luquet, Wade

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384402?accountid=14667

Abstract: The history of the professionalization of social work often begins with the men of Toynbee Hall who inspired the settlement movement in the United Kingdom and the United States. But is it possible that an earlier group inspired them? The research presented here raises the question of whether the work of the noncloistered Sisters of Mercy may have been a prototype of the settlement movement in England. With their secular beginning in Ireland in 1824, the sisters opened Houses of Mercy in Ireland (1827) and England (1839) and eventually throughout the world to provide relief to the poor through charity, job training, education, health care, and counseling. This article presents original documents to illustrate their work and to open the question of the sisters' role in the history of social welfare. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Contribution+of+the+Sisters+of+Mercy+to+the+Development+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.au=Luquet%2C+Wade&amp;rft.aulast=Luquet&amp;rft.aufirst=Wade&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Contribution+of+the+Sisters+of+Mercy+to+the+Development+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.au=Luquet%2C+Wade&amp;rft.aulast=Luquet&amp;rft.aufirst=Wade&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

"We Are More Than Jailbirds": An Arts Program for Incarcerated Young Women

Author: Lazzari, Marceline M; Amundson, Kathryn A; Jackson, Robert L

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215397495?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents the findings of a qualitative study of the effects of an innovative arts project on incarcerated female juvenile offenders. In this project, a professional artist engages and guides the detainees in the creation of individual and collaborative artistic works. The works of art are produced for museum display to enhance the development of the young women's self-identity and to draw public attention to the incarceration of young women in the juvenile justice system. The findings of this study are corroborated and supported by relational-cultural and self-efficacy theoretical perspectives. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22We+Are+More+Than+Jailbirds%22%3A+An+Arts+Program+for+Incarcerated+Young+Women&amp;rft.au=Lazzari%2C+Marceline+M%3BAmundson%2C+Kathryn+A%3BJackson%2C+Robert+L&amp;rft.aulast=Lazzari&amp;rft.aufirst=Marceline&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=169&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Computer Technology for the Feminist Classroom

Author: Littlefield, Melissa B; Roberson, Kendra C

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215397544?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents an evaluation of a social work course on oppression and diversity in which an interactive Web page was used to structure feminist learning experiences. Three assignments are described-- an online diversity discussion board, a "digital poster" group research project, and the summary and critique of articles. The evaluation found that several processes that are key to a feminist classroom were achieved, including community building, collaboration, peer learning, empowerment, and the development of leadership capacity. The majority of students thought that the class was a supportive, collaborative environment in which they were able to achieve their learning goals. Implications for using technology to structure feminist learning experiences are discussed. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Computer+Technology+for+the+Feminist+Classroom&amp;rft.au=Littlefield%2C+Melissa+B%3BRoberson%2C+Kendra+C&amp;rft.aulast=Littlefield&amp;rft.aufirst=Melissa&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=186&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Navigating Mixed-Theory Programs: Lessons Learned From a Prostitution-Diversion Project

Author: Wahab, Stephanie

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215392104?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses some findings of a qualitative evaluation of Salt Lake City's Prostitution Diversion Project (conducted in 2003-2004) to expose some of the challenges and opportunities of mixed-theory projects. The findings focus specifically on project stakeholders' recommendations for improving the program. Many of these recommendations are related to the tensions that manifested between the two major stakeholders: Criminal Justice Services and the Harm Reduction Project. The unlikely relationship between these stakeholders is what distinguished the Salt Lake City project from other prostitution-diversion programs in the United States and Canada. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Navigating+Mixed-Theory+Programs%3A+Lessons+Learned+From+a+Prostitution-Diversion+Project&amp;rft.au=Wahab%2C+Stephanie&amp;rft.aulast=Wahab&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=203&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Savings Experiences Past and Present: Narratives From Low-Income African American Women

Author: Shobe, Marcia A; Christy-McMullin, Kameri

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215390237?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research has found that low-income individuals can and do save when institutional supports are in place; however, little structured data are available on how and why they manage to save. This article presents a study of the long-term savings experiences of 9 low-income African American women who were participating in an Individual Development Account (IDA) savings program in a city in North Carolina. The results indicated that despite many markers of disadvantage, low-income African American women use various strategies to save money for developing their assets. These findings can inform policy, practice, and research by increasing knowledge of facilitators of and barriers to the development of assets among the poor. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Savings+Experiences+Past+and+Present%3A+Narratives+From+Low-Income+African+American+Women&amp;rft.au=Shobe%2C+Marcia+A%3BChristy-McMullin%2C+Kameri&amp;rft.aulast=Shobe&amp;rft.aufirst=Marcia&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=222&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Savings+Experiences+Past+and+Present%3A+Narratives+From+Low-Income+African+American+Women&amp;rft.au=Shobe%2C+Marcia+A%3BChristy-McMullin%2C+Kameri&amp;rft.aulast=Shobe&amp;rft.aufirst=Marcia&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=222&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Reexamining What We Think We Know: A Lesson Learned From Tamil Refugees

Author: Weaver, Hilary N

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395261?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes a project designed to create a culturally appropriate tool to assess trauma in Tamil people who have fled civil war in Sri Lanka. In addition to being culturally appropriate, the project sought to determine if the assessment tool would adequately measure trauma experienced by women. Despite concern that Tamil women would be reluctant to discuss sexual assault, in this project women did indeed describe their traumatic experiences and often preferred to do so in the presence of multiple people. Notably, Tamil men also commonly stated that they experienced sexual assault. As social workers, we are reminded that there is a continual need to question assumptions, especially those about what we expect people from a particular culture to think, believe, and do. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Reexamining+What+We+Think+We+Know%3A+A+Lesson+Learned+From+Tamil+Refugees&amp;rft.au=Weaver%2C+Hilary+N&amp;rft.aulast=Weaver&amp;rft.aufirst=Hilary&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=238&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Reexamining+What+We+Think+We+Know%3A+A+Lesson+Learned+From+Tamil+Refugees&amp;rft.au=Weaver%2C+Hilary+N&amp;rft.aulast=Weaver&amp;rft.aufirst=Hilary&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=238&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Pride, Prejudice, and a Dose of Shame: The Meaning of Public Assistance

Author: Gray, Karen A11 College of Social Work, University of South Carolina

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/811277302?accountid=14667

Abstract: Little is known about women's retrospective views on the receipt of public assistance, including their relationships with their caseworkers. This article examines the findings of 20 in-depth interviews with women about their experiences with public assistance after they went from public assistance to a living-wage job. The respondents' self-stories are interpreted using a social constructionist framework.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Pride%2C+Prejudice%2C+and+a+Dose+of+Shame%3A+The+Meaning+of+Public+Assistance&amp;rft.au=Gray%2C+Karen+A&amp;rft.aulast=Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2005-08-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=329&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109905277752

Addie Hunton and the Construction of an African American Female Peace Perspective

Author: Chandler, Susan

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395397?accountid=14667

Abstract: Addie Hunton, a major 20th-century African American social welfare professional, served in France with the American Expeditionary Forces during World War I. Sobered and politicized by the experience of war and the prejudice that she witnessed, Hunton dedicated the remainder of her life to fighting for peace and racial justice. Her work, which both mirrored and differed from the contributions of peace-minded women social workers such as Jane Addams and Jeannette Rankin, unfolded a dialectic between social service work and peace that argued that global peace is impossible without "right local relations," that is, dignity, equality, and well-being for all people.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Addie+Hunton+and+the+Construction+of+an+African+American+Female+Peace+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Chandler%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Chandler&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=270&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Addie+Hunton+and+the+Construction+of+an+African+American+Female+Peace+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Chandler%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Chandler&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=270&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Social Construction of Concealment Among Chinese Women in Abusive Marriages in Hong Kong

Author: Yuen-Tsang, Angelina; Sung, Pauline

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215400733?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents the findings of a qualitative study of 15 Chinese women in Hong Kong who experienced marital conflict and family violence. Adopting a narrative approach, the authors found that the women had gradually developed a culture of concealment through a process of social construction. Individual, environmental, and cultural factors had combined to develop and reinforce their tendency to conceal their situation and to remain silent. This culture of concealment was highly oppressive and had a negative impact on the women’s personal, interpersonal, and social well-being. Social work strategies to break this pattern of behavior and to liberate the women from the culture of concealment are explored.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Social+Construction+of+Concealment+Among+Chinese+Women+in+Abusive+Marriages+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Yuen-Tsang%2C+Angelina%3BSung%2C+Pauline&amp;rft.aulast=Yuen-Tsang&amp;rft.aufirst=Angelina&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=284&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Social+Construction+of+Concealment+Among+Chinese+Women+in+Abusive+Marriages+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Yuen-Tsang%2C+Angelina%3BSung%2C+Pauline&amp;rft.aulast=Yuen-Tsang&amp;rft.aufirst=Angelina&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=284&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

"Disease and Delinquency Know No Color": Syphilis and African American Female Delinquency

Author: Tanya Smith Brice

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215387932?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the nuances of female delinquency, as it was labeled, during the early 1900s from a medical and social perspective, particularly its manifestation among African American girls. It also examines the efforts made by African American women in early 20th-century North Carolina to address what was deemed female delinquency, as well as syphilis, among these young girls.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22Disease+and+Delinquency+Know+No+Color%22%3A+Syphilis+and+African+American+Female+Delinquency&amp;rft.au=Tanya+Smith+Brice&amp;rft.aulast=Tanya+Smith+Brice&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=300&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Nature and Impact of Domestic Violence Across Age Cohorts

Author: Wilke, Dina J; Vinton, Linda

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395092?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the nature and extent of domestic violence and its impact on psychosocial functioning among women of different age groups. No differences were found across age groups in the severity of violence, nature of injuries, use of alcohol or drugs at the time of the incident, attribution of blame, likelihood to report violence, or rates of childhood physical abuse and depression. However, the older women were more likely to have experienced violence for a longer time, to be in current violent relationships, and to have health and mental health problems than were the younger women. These similarities and differences are discussed in terms of interventions.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Nature+and+Impact+of+Domestic+Violence+Across+Age+Cohorts&amp;rft.au=Wilke%2C+Dina+J%3BVinton%2C+Linda&amp;rft.aulast=Wilke&amp;rft.aufirst=Dina&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=316&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215391936?accountid=14667

The respondents' self-stories are interpreted using a social constructionist framework.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Survivors' Opinions About Mandatory Reporting of Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault by Medical Professionals

Author: Sullivan, Cris M; Hagen, Leslie A

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215386305?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sixty-one survivors of domestic or sexual abuse participated in focus groups to discuss their perceptions of mandatory reporting by health care professionals. Only one participant believed that medical providers should notify the police when a woman seeks treatment. This survivor's experience was different from that of most of the other participants in that she was raped by a stranger. The remaining participants were unanimous in their belief that medical reporting should not be mandatory until a number of changes are made in the system to promote victims' safety. The survivors shared numerous examples of having been revictimized by the child protection system, health care system, mass media, and especially the criminal legal system. Practice, policy, and research implications are discussed.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Survivors%27+Opinions+About+Mandatory+Reporting+of+Domestic+Violence+and+Sexual+Assault+by+Medical+Professionals&amp;rft.au=Sullivan%2C+Cris+M%3BHagen%2C+Leslie+A&amp;rft.aulast=Sullivan&amp;rft.aufirst=Cris&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=346&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Flora's Vest: The Personal Is Political Is Personal Again

Author: Danis, Fran S

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395147?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sexual violence against girls and young women may have contributed to the reasons why Jews left Russia in the early 1900s and immigrated to the United States. Acommon feature of anti-Jewish pogroms rape continues today to be an instrument of war and oppression. The author speculates on the reasons why her great grandmother left Russia alone at age 18 to sail for America, and draws connections between her work today and her family herstory.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Flora%27s+Vest%3A+The+Personal+Is+Political+Is+Personal+Again&amp;rft.au=Danis%2C+Fran+S&amp;rft.aulast=Danis&amp;rft.aufirst=Fran&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=362&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

When Bodies Need Voices: Sharing Stories of Survival

Author: McCarthy, Maria; Weber, Zita

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384347?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article elaborates the theme: Accidentally Learning More About Life which was the title of a presentation forum in which the authors met. Links are made between the views of the academic listener with the lived experience of a woman for whom an accident changed her life narrative. Maria's story demonstrates how adversity can lead to positive outcomes and that in retelling the story, you can make a difference. Maria's story also exemplifies how a woman can challenge gender-stereotypic assumptions and confirm that the personal is always the political.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=When+Bodies+Need+Voices%3A+Sharing+Stories+of+Survival&amp;rft.au=McCarthy%2C+Maria%3BWeber%2C+Zita&amp;rft.aulast=McCarthy&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=2005-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=368&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Belief in Personal Control Among Low-Income African American, Puerto Rican, and European American Single Mothers

Author: Sparks, Anne1; Peterson, NAndrew; Tangenberg, Kathleen1 Department of Social Work, Ohio University, Morton Hall 416, Athens, OH 45701

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/811225280?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined belief in personal control among low-income single mothers (African American, Puerto Rican, and European American) in an economically distressed region in the Northeast, who were recruited from child care centers and community programs. A factor analysis of the Belief in Personal Control Scale supported the three hypothesized subscales of the measure-God-mediated control, external control, and exaggerated personal control. The results indicate that African American women had stronger God-mediated control and weaker external control than did European American women and that Puerto Rican women had greater external control and weaker exaggerated personal control than did European American women. They suggest that an instrument that measures belief in personal control can contribute to efforts to understand low-income single mothers' perceptions of their situations and that religious faith should be further explored as a key component of belief in personal control.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Belief+in+Personal+Control+Among+Low-Income+African+American%2C+Puerto+Rican%2C+and+European+American+Single+Mothers&amp;rft.au=Sparks%2C+Anne%3BPeterson%2C+NAndrew%3BTangenberg%2C+Kathleen&amp;rft.aulast=Sparks&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=401&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109905279872

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Belief+in+Personal+Control+Among+Low-Income+African+American%2C+Puerto+Rican%2C+and+European+American+Single+Mothers&amp;rft.au=Sparks%2C+Anne%3BPeterson%2C+NAndrew%3BTangenberg%2C+Kathleen&amp;rft.aulast=Sparks&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=401&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109905279872

The Era of Meanness: Welfare Reform and Barriers to a College Degree

Author: Weikart, Lynne A11 Baruch College School of Public Affairs, City University of New York, 17 Lexington Avenue, Box D901, New York, NY 10010, lynne_weikart@baruch.cuny.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/811291455?accountid=14667

Abstract: In response to the passage of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 and the accompanying block grant, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, broad-based advocacy coalitions formed in many states to lobby for meaningful college programs for welfare recipients. State by state, these coalitions wrestled with creating programs that would allow welfare recipients to remain in 4-year colleges, but only a few states managed to develop such programs. This article compares the advocacy coalitions in two states, Maine and New York, where welfare advocates struggled to achieve progressive state welfare higher educational policies and, in some instances, succeeded in keeping welfare recipients in 4-year colleges.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Era+of+Meanness%3A+Welfare+Reform+and+Barriers+to+a+College+Degree&amp;rft.au=Weikart%2C+Lynne+A&amp;rft.aulast=Weikart&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynne&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=416&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109905279802

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Era+of+Meanness%3A+Welfare+Reform+and+Barriers+to+a+College+Degree&amp;rft.au=Weikart%2C+Lynne+A&amp;rft.aulast=Weikart&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynne&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=416&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109905279802

A Narrative Principle for Feminist Social Work With Survivors of Male Violence

Author: Roche, Susan E1; Wood, Gale Goldberg1 Department of Social Work, University of Vermont, 436 A Waterman Building, Burlington, VT 05405

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/811280254?accountid=14667

Abstract: Blame surrounds and embeds male violence against women, acting as oppressive propaganda that shapes survivors' identities, which, in turn, reduce their options. This article challenges the notion that violence against women renders women passive and precludes their resistance. It describes a narrative practice principle-coconstructing women's new identity stories-to guide social work in countering this propaganda with women survivors of male violence. Blame is addressed as a cultural narrative within which some women are targeted by male violence and all women construct their identities. As a feminist social work principle, coconstructing women's new identity stories connects the political and the individual facets of male violence, expanding women's options for action. Specifically, the article presents the principle and three processes for translating it into action.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=A+Narrative+Principle+for+Feminist+Social+Work+With+Survivors+of+Male+Violence&amp;rft.au=Roche%2C+Susan+E%3BWood%2C+Gale+Goldberg&amp;rft.aulast=Roche&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=465&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109905279960

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=A+Narrative+Principle+for+Feminist+Social+Work+With+Survivors+of+Male+Violence&amp;rft.au=Roche%2C+Susan+E%3BWood%2C+Gale+Goldberg&amp;rft.aulast=Roche&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=465&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109905279960

____________________________________________________________

Cyberspace and Child Abuse Images: A Feminist Perspective

Author: Harrison, Christine

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215385986?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article approaches cyberspace as a socially constructed space in which gendered power relations are replicated and examines how cyberspace has been expropriated to escalate child sexual abuse and other sexual offenses. Making connections between different forms of abuse of women and children demonstrates that feminist perspectives provide an essential framework for understanding how new information and communication technologies are reinforcing attitudes that degrade and dehumanize women and children. Analyzing the relationship between gender and other oppressions challenges the hegemony of discourses that emphasize freedom and the democratizing potential of cyberspace and shows how cyberspace is a site for increased violence and exploitation of women and children. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Cyberspace+and+Child+Abuse+Images%3A+A+Feminist+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Harrison%2C+Christine&amp;rft.aulast=Harrison&amp;rft.aufirst=Christine&amp;rft.date=2006-12-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=365&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Cyberspace+and+Child+Abuse+Images%3A+A+Feminist+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Harrison%2C+Christine&amp;rft.aulast=Harrison&amp;rft.aufirst=Christine&amp;rft.date=2006-12-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=365&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Virginia: A Story of Conflict in Social Work Field Education

Author: Barlow, Constance A; Phelan, Anne; Hurlock, Deborah; Sawa, Russell; et al

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395088?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article considers the case of Virginia, a social work practicum student who experienced conflict in her field placement, in light of Heilbrun's notion of liminality--that is, being poised on uncertain ground, leaving one condition or self and entering another. In addition, Virginia's experience is explored within the complex web of power and resistance that characterized her relationship with the field instructor, the agency director, and the school. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Virginia%3A+A+Story+of+Conflict+in+Social+Work+Field+Education&amp;rft.au=Barlow%2C+Constance+A%3BPhelan%2C+Anne%3BHurlock%2C+Deborah%3BSawa%2C+Russell%3Bet+al&amp;rft.aulast=Barlow&amp;rft.aufirst=Constance&amp;rft.date=2006-12-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=380&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Women and Men With Mental Illnesses: Voicing Different Service Needs

Author: Scheyett, Anna M; McCarthy, Erin

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215394622?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women with mental illnesses have reported that one painful aspect of living with their diagnosis is the loss of personal identity when they are labeled "mentally ill." Although a number of studies have focused on services to address issues of relevance to women, few have explored the different ways in which women and men view services within the mental health system. Using a focus-group approach, the authors conducted a study that examined the service needs and views of women and men with mental illnesses. This article reports on this study and identifies the participants' common and unique needs and views and discusses the implications for research and practice. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Women+and+Men+With+Mental+Illnesses%3A+Voicing+Different+Service+Needs&amp;rft.au=Scheyett%2C+Anna+M%3BMcCarthy%2C+Erin&amp;rft.aulast=Scheyett&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2006-12-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=407&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Empowering the "Unfit" Mother: Increasing Empathy, Redefining the Label

Author: Smith, Nora A

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215400322?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents the results of a qualitative study that examined the experiences of women who were deemed "unfit" to care for their children. The voices of these mothers call attention to the difficult process of recovery from addiction while trying to regain custody of one's children. A strengths-based empowerment approach is emphasized in work with these women, beginning with a redefinition of the label "unfit." [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Empowering+the+%22Unfit%22+Mother%3A+Increasing+Empathy%2C+Redefining+the+Label&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Nora+A&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Nora&amp;rft.date=2006-12-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=448&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Professionalizing Social Work at the National Level: Women Social Work Leaders, 1910-1982

Author: Stotzer, Rebecca L; Tropman, John E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384237?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines the presidential addresses of the 21 women presidents of the National Conference of Social Work. Although content analysis is difficult because the speeches cross seven decades, three components stood out: The women presidents primarily used their expertise as power, used partisan leadership techniques with a conservative slant, and avoided discussing women or women's issues. The authors argue that these three stylistic components reflect the common desire of the women presidents to advance the professional status of social work, under conditions of subdominant professional and gendered status, despite the span of years. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Professionalizing+Social+Work+at+the+National+Level%3A+Women+Social+Work+Leaders%2C+1910-1982&amp;rft.au=Stotzer%2C+Rebecca+L%3BTropman%2C+John+E&amp;rft.aulast=Stotzer&amp;rft.aufirst=Rebecca&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Law Enforcement Versus Battered Women: The Conflict Over the Lautenberg Amendment

Author: Adelman, Madelaine; Morgan, Phoebe

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388185?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since the early 1970s, law enforcement agencies have made great strides in improving their response to domestic violence. However, attempts to reform the 1996 Domestic Violence Offender Gun Ban Act (P.L. 104-208, section 658, 1997) pitted law enforcement against the battered women's movement. Contra predictions of system equilibrium, in this competition--between the victims of the new law (law enforcement officers) and the victims whom the new law intended to protect (battered women)--decision makers chose battered women over law enforcement officers. This article examines why this conflict developed, identifies the strategies that won in this conflict, and considers the impact of this conflict on domestic violence. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Law+Enforcement+Versus+Battered+Women%3A+The+Conflict+Over+the+Lautenberg+Amendment&amp;rft.au=Adelman%2C+Madelaine%3BMorgan%2C+Phoebe&amp;rft.aulast=Adelman&amp;rft.aufirst=Madelaine&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=28&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Law+Enforcement+Versus+Battered+Women%3A+The+Conflict+Over+the+Lautenberg+Amendment&amp;rft.au=Adelman%2C+Madelaine%3BMorgan%2C+Phoebe&amp;rft.aulast=Adelman&amp;rft.aufirst=Madelaine&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=28&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Acculturation and the Mental Health of Latina Women in the Women, Infant, and Children Program

Author: Cordero, Antonia; Kurz, Brenda

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215386206?accountid=14667

Abstract: Studies have reported discrepant findings about the relationship between acculturation and mental health, often because of inattention to interethnic group differences. This 2003 exploratory study of various Latina ethnic groups attending the Women, Infant, and Children (WIC) Program compared five measures of acculturation and mental health status/utilization. The subgroups differed on language, immigration/migration history, and the prevalence of anxiety attacks and depressive syndrome. The prevalence of anxiety attacks was the highest among those who spoke primarily Spanish, the prevalence of the depressive syndrome was the highest among those with more traditional beliefs, and the use of mental health services was the highest among those with less traditional beliefs. Implications for practice are discussed. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Acculturation+and+the+Mental+Health+of+Latina+Women+in+the+Women%2C+Infant%2C+and+Children+Program&amp;rft.au=Cordero%2C+Antonia%3BKurz%2C+Brenda&amp;rft.aulast=Cordero&amp;rft.aufirst=Antonia&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=46&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Acculturation+and+the+Mental+Health+of+Latina+Women+in+the+Women%2C+Infant%2C+and+Children+Program&amp;rft.au=Cordero%2C+Antonia%3BKurz%2C+Brenda&amp;rft.aulast=Cordero&amp;rft.aufirst=Antonia&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=46&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Acculturation; Mental health; Hispanics; Women

Title: Acculturation and the Mental Health of Latina Women in the Women, Infant, and Children Program

Using Feminist Methods and Restorative Justice to Interview Capital Offenders' Family Members

Author: Beck, Elizabeth; Britto, Sarah

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215394771?accountid=14667

Abstract: Researching sensitive topics is critical to understanding women's lives. However, this research often carries the risk of retraumatization and exploitation. This article examines the development of a sensitive-topic interview protocol that sought to minimize harm and to gain reliable and valid data by using principles from feminist methods and theory, and restorative justice. The development of the protocol is examined and its effectiveness is explored in a postinterview survey of family members of capital offenders. The data indicate that the methods minimized harm and that the protocol resulted in a robust understanding of the participants' lived experience from their perspectives. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Feminist+Methods+and+Restorative+Justice+to+Interview+Capital+Offenders%27+Family+Members&amp;rft.au=Beck%2C+Elizabeth%3BBritto%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=Beck&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=59&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Our "Ideal Girl": Prescriptions of Female Adolescent Sexuality in a Feminist Mentorship Program

Author: Bay-Cheng, Laina Y; Lewis, Amanda E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388234?accountid=14667

Abstract: Adolescent girls must contend with several sets of competing expectations at the discursive intersection of sexuality, age, gender, and race. This article examines how a feminist mentorship program for early adolescent girls engaged the issue of sexuality. Despite the program's self-described feminist orientation, ethnographic analysis revealed its reliance on moralistic, age-based standards of appropriate sexual interest and behavior; the suppression of sexuality; and girl-as-victim discourse. These data bolster the call for reformed, sex-positive approaches to adolescent sexuality and reveal some of the complexities involved in cross-generational feminist interventions. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Our+%22Ideal+Girl%22%3A+Prescriptions+of+Female+Adolescent+Sexuality+in+a+Feminist+Mentorship+Program&amp;rft.au=Bay-Cheng%2C+Laina+Y%3BLewis%2C+Amanda+E&amp;rft.aulast=Bay-Cheng&amp;rft.aufirst=Laina&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Women, Abuse, and the Welfare Bureaucracy

Author: Laakso, Janice H; Drevdahl, Denise J

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215384073?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using critical and feminist theoretical frameworks, this report of a qualitative study describes women's perspectives of the welfare bureaucracy. An analysis of interviews with 38 women revealed emotional and economic abuse both in the welfare system and their personal lives. Interactions with frontline workers who implement the rules and regulations of welfare reform disempower recipients and mimic the conditions of abuse that these women have already experienced. Genograms provide a context for the women's personal histories. Recommendations include removing sanctions as a form of economic abuse, screening every applicant for interpersonal violence, and referring women to mental health services if necessary. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Women%2C+Abuse%2C+and+the+Welfare+Bureaucracy&amp;rft.au=Laakso%2C+Janice+H%3BDrevdahl%2C+Denise+J&amp;rft.aulast=Laakso&amp;rft.aufirst=Janice&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=84&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Changing My Mind: An Encounter With Jane Addams

Author: Knight, Louise W

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215391794?accountid=14667

Abstract: In writing a half-life biography of Jane Addams, the author faced the difficult decision of choosing a point of view from which to interpret her life. She knew that somehow she would have to find a way to be wiser than Jane Addams--at least the adult Jane Addams--and she was not sure, given the narrowness of her life when compared to hers, that she could. Eventually, however, the author realized she could compare Addams to herself. By 1899, when the biography ends, after 10 years at Hull House, Addams's ideas about the morality of the labor movement, the adaptability of social ethics to their times, and about her own class's presumed superiority to working-class people had changed from what she had believed in 1889. Addams’s continuing determination to face her own moral confusions and revise her ideas shaped her life and offers an example from which many can learn. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Changing+My+Mind%3A+An+Encounter+With+Jane+Addams&amp;rft.au=Knight%2C+Louise+W&amp;rft.aulast=Knight&amp;rft.aufirst=Louise&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=97&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Changing+My+Mind%3A+An+Encounter+With+Jane+Addams&amp;rft.au=Knight%2C+Louise+W&amp;rft.aulast=Knight&amp;rft.aufirst=Louise&amp;rft.date=2006-04-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=97&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Gender and War: The Effects of Armed Conflict on Women's Health and Mental Health

Author: Jansen, Golie G

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215395144?accountid=14667

Abstract: Gender inequality is magnified in situations of war, and women are disproportionately disadvantaged in terms of personal safety, access to resources, and human rights. This article summarizes the effects of armed conflict on women and women's greater vulnerability to health and mental health concerns because in war, women's bodies become a battleground. UN Security Council Resolution 1325 is introduced as an international framework to address women's participation in solutions to war, reconstruction, and nation building. The article also indicates ways in which socialworkers can be part of implementing this resolution to defend the human rights of women. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Gender+and+War%3A+The+Effects+of+Armed+Conflict+on+Women%27s+Health+and+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Jansen%2C+Golie+G&amp;rft.aulast=Jansen&amp;rft.aufirst=Golie&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=134&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Feminine Virtue and Feminist Fervor: The Impact of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom in the 1930s

Author: Hensley, Melissa Anne

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215391667?accountid=14667

Abstract: Because of the success of woman suffrage and concerns about World War I, women activists became involved in promoting peace. The Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF) was a prominent organization in this movement, taking an active part in both national and international political processes. Issues of interest to the WILPF during the 1930s included international disarmament, investigation of the munitions industry, and racial justice. Red-baiting, along with the unpopularity of pacifism prior to World War II, lessened the influence of the WILPF. However, today's social workers can learn much from the WILPF's efforts of 70 years ago. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Feminine+Virtue+and+Feminist+Fervor%3A+The+Impact+of+the+Women%27s+International+League+for+Peace+and+Freedom+in+the+1930s&amp;rft.au=Hensley%2C+Melissa+Anne&amp;rft.aulast=Hensley&amp;rft.aufirst=Melissa&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=146&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Feminine+Virtue+and+Feminist+Fervor%3A+The+Impact+of+the+Women%27s+International+League+for+Peace+and+Freedom+in+the+1930s&amp;rft.au=Hensley%2C+Melissa+Anne&amp;rft.aulast=Hensley&amp;rft.aufirst=Melissa&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=146&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Speaking Truth to Power: Jane Addams's Values Base for Peacemaking

Author: Kosterman, Eleanor M; Stratton, Dorothy C

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215388131?accountid=14667

Abstract: Jane Addams is known for founding Hull-House and for her leadership in the emerging social work profession. But little scholarly attention has centered on the values that influenced her emergence as an internationally known social activist and pacifist. The findings include a congruity with Quaker beliefs and early social work values but no attempt to identify herself as a member of either group. Despite intense opposition, Addams led the early 20th-century women's peace movement, unwavering in her belief that women's nurturing experiences led them to value life deeply and that women's involvement in world political affairs would bring about a more humane and peaceful society. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Speaking+Truth+to+Power%3A+Jane+Addams%27s+Values+Base+for+Peacemaking&amp;rft.au=Kosterman%2C+Eleanor+M%3BStratton%2C+Dorothy+C&amp;rft.aulast=Kosterman&amp;rft.aufirst=Eleanor&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=158&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apqrl&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Speaking+Truth+to+Power%3A+Jane+Addams%27s+Values+Base+for+Peacemaking&amp;rft.au=Kosterman%2C+Eleanor+M%3BStratton%2C+Dorothy+C&amp;rft.aulast=Kosterman&amp;rft.aufirst=Eleanor&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=158&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
